thread.title: Local Roundup: Reinhardt leaps into top 10
thread.title_full: Local Roundup: Reinhardt leaps into top 10

author: Tribune staff reports (noreply@cherokeetribune.com)
title: Local Roundup: Reinhardt leaps into top 10
text: Local Roundup: Reinhardt leaps into top 10 by Tribune staff reports Cherokee Tribune October 14, 2015 12:59 AM | 174 views | 0 | 2 | | For the third time in four weeks, Reinhardt jumped five spots in the NAIA rankings, this time to No. 8. The Eagles (6-0, 1-0 Mid-South West) received the boost after coming back from 18 points down to beat then-No. 10 Faulkner 55-27 on Saturday.Quarterback Ryan Thompson came up huge in the game, throwing for a season-high 347 yards and two touchdowns to be named the NAIA offensive player of the week. It was the first time a Reinhardt player had been recognized nationally in the program’s three-year history.The junior from Mary Esther, Florida, eclipsed the 300-yard mark for the second time in his career, and he is the only Reinhardt passer to do so. He also threw for two touchdowns, ran the ball eight times for 48 yards and performed well under pressure, converting two fourth-down plays.In addition to the national recognition, Thompson joined Marcus Miller as Mid-South Conference honorees. Thompson was the conference’s offensive player of the week, while Miller was awarded special teams player of the week after returning a blocked punt 45 yards for a score.Miller, who was named the Mid-South’s West defensive freshman of the year last season, leads the Eagles with 23 solo tackles. He became Reinhardt’s first non-returner to win the special teams award.Reinhardt will take the field again Saturday when it travels to Lebanon, Tennessee, for a division game against Cumberland.♦ ♦ ♦Football was not the only sport in which Reinhardt athletes were recognized for their performances.Soccer players Torge Wiedenroth and Katie Goodrich were honored by the Appalachian Athletic Conference as defensive and offensive players of the week, respectively.Wiedenroth was awarded after his play in goal led the Reinhardt men’s soccer team to a pair of conference wins last week. The freshman made three saves in a 2-1 win over Truett-McConnell and seven saves in a 2-1 win over Tennessee Wesleyan.The Eagles (6-5, 4-1) surrendered a goal in the last minute of the first half against Tennessee Wesleyan to find themselves in a hole, but second-half goals from Dodge Palmisano and Matthew Gray completed the comeback win. On the women’s side, Goodrich was awarded after leading Reinhardt to two conference wins last week. The sophomore forward came off the bench to score the winning goal in a 3-1 victory over Truett-McConnell and added another in a 4-2 win over Tennessee Wesleyan.Much like in the men’s game, the Lady Eagles (9-1-1, 4-1) also needed a comeback to beat Tennessee Wesleyan. Trailing 2-1 with 20 minutes to play, Reinhardt rallied to score three goals in a 15-minute stretch.Megan McCall started the comeback, scoring her second goal of the game in the 71st minute. Lindsey White added the go-ahead goal in the 82nd minute, and Goodrich put the game out of reach with her score in the 85th minute.Both teams will be back in action today, with the women visiting Georgia Gwinnett and the men traveling to Barbourville, Kentucky, to face No. 16 Union.♦ ♦ ♦Liam Byrne threw for 345 yards, ran for 3, had 15 yards receiving and accounted for four total touchdowns as Woodstock’s offensive player of the week in a 37-22 win over Cherokee. Dashaun Tanner and Jerrail McMickens were awarded on defense and special teams, respectively, after Tanner returned an interception for a score and McMickens blocked a punt for a safety.Cherokee named tight end Brock Thompson its offensive player of the week after he made his first catch of the year for 44 yards. Adam Mayo was honored on defense with nine tackles from the defensive line, and Montrell Washington was named special teams player of the week after his 75-yard kickoff return touchdown in the fourth quarter kept the game close.Josh Horowitz was Creekview’s offensive player of the week. The guard helped allowing the Grizzlies rack up 464 yards of offense in a 42-17 win over Woodland. Linebacker Dylan Carl won the award on defense after recording 14 tackles, one sack and a forced fumble.Patrick Ferris was named Etowah’s offensive player of the week after completing 12 of 16 passes for 216 yards and three scores in a 38-20 win at Milton. Safety Stuart Head was named defensive player of the week after leading a unit that only allowed six second-half points, and Joe Vicznesky was awarded on special teams.Running back Cameron Gales rushed for 48 yards and two touchdowns on 15 carries to be named Sequoyah’s offensive player of the week following a 24-3 win at Cass. Hakeem Hartford recorded six tackles, including one for a loss, to be named the defensive player and Darius Smith was the special teams player.Thompson was named Reinhardt’s offensive player of the week, while Hunter Oswald was named defensive player after he recorded two tackles for loss and led a unit that only surrendered six points over the final 43 minutes of game time. Quincy Standifer, with six tackles, was the Eagles’ special teams player, while Tre Coney and Alex Gardner were recognized as the offensive and defensive scout team players of the week.
